results.title: Rocky
results.creator_credit: John G. Avildsen, Irwin Winkler, Robert Chartoff and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone), otherwise known as the “Italian Stallion” is an underdog challenged to fight the reigning heavyweight champion, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers). Unperturbed and inspired by his dedicated manger Mickey (Burgess Meredith) and girlfriend Adrian (Talia Shire), Rocky has his eyes on the prize and a motivation to win. It is his one chance at fortune, self-respect, love and the world heavyweight crown. Filmed in only twenty eight days and with a screenplay written by Sylvester Stallone, “Rocky” won three Academy Awards including Best Picture.

results.title: The Symphony orchestra
results.brief_description: The composer who creates symphonic music must still rely on the efforts of many other musicians for a performance of his work; and the conductor of the orchestra which is to perform a symphonic work is largely responsible for the interpretation placed on the work of the composer whose work they are to play. In this film, the function of the various choirs of the orchestra is demonstrated, as Howard Barlow conducts the Columbia Symphony Orchestra in a performance of Wagner’s “Ride of the Valkyries” and the Prelude to Act III of “Lohengrin”.

results.title: Oil Review. No. 09
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Swingler, Film Producers Guild and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: The story of the building of a new bridge over the River Karun in South-West Persia. The film shows the difficult nature of the mountain country over which material for the bridge had to be transported. Finally the river is conquered and the strong, delicate steelwork of the bridge spans its summer sloth and its winter torrent, a safe, sure way for all who wish to cross.

results.title: Time piece
results.creator_credit: Albert Kish, Colin Low and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Examples of restoration projects undertaken by Canada’s National Historic Sites Service. Fort Louisbourg, painstakingly rebuilt to its former imposing dimensions on Nova Scotia’s Cape Breton coast; near Winnipeg, a century-old Hudson’s Bay Company trading post; in Kingston, the home of Sir John A. Macdonald; and famous Dawson City, are some of the many places and mementos of the past vividly brought to life in this film.

results.title: Paddington goes to the movies
results.creator_credit: Barry Leith, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington
results.brief_description: Paddington is caught in a storm and shelters in the entrance of a cinema where he discovers that “Singing in the Rain” starring Gene Kelly is screening. Being an unaccompanied bear under 16, Paddington is not allowed in. However, he manages to peer through a keyhole and catches his first glimpse of the world of the silver screen. Unfortunately, in typical Paddington fashion, he also wreaks havoc in the theatre and the projection box. On his way home, in the excitement of the moment, Paddington tries to emulate the dancing of Gene Kelly. Narrated by Michael Hordern and based on the book by Michael Bond. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.
